articleBody: Learning Objectives â€¢ Understand the relationship between ISO, brightness, and noise in photography. â€¢ Learn to control exposure using aperture and shutter speed while fixing ISO. â€¢ Develop the ability to assess and choose the appropriate ISO setting for different scenarios. Learn More & Join Download Assignment PDF Before You Shoot â€¢ Ensure your camera is fully charged and has sufficient storage. â€¢ Familiarize yourself with your camera's ISO settings and modes. â€¢ Select a location with varied lighting conditions. â€¢ Choose subjects that will allow you to test the limits of ISO and noise. â€¢ Prepare a notebook or digital device for taking notes on your settings and evaluations. The Assignment Technical Focus â€¢ Set your ISO to a fixed value (e.g., ISO 200) to control noise levels. â€¢ Experiment with different aperture settings to see their effect on depth of field. â€¢ Use different shutter speeds to observe how they affect motion capture. â€¢ Evaluate the quality of images taken at various ISO settings in low light. â€¢ Pay attention to the noise levels in your images and identify settings that minimize it. Creative Focus â€¢ Explore creative compositions that require low light settings. â€¢ Use shallow depth of field to highlight subjects while managing ISO. â€¢ Incorporate movement in your shots to see how ISO affects motion blur. â€¢ Try different lighting conditions, such as dusk or dawn, to challenge your ISO settings. â€¢ Experiment with textures and patterns in low light to assess noise impact on detail. Assignment Tasks â€¢ Use aperture priority mode at f/2.8 with ISO 200 fixed, letting the camera set shutter speed in a dimly lit room to capture detail without excessive noise. â€¢ Set your camera to shutter priority mode at 1/250s with ISO 200 fixed, capturing moving subjects in a park to assess how ISO affects motion clarity. â€¢ In a twilight setting, use aperture priority mode at f/5.6 with ISO 200 fixed, allowing the camera to adjust shutter speed while observing the noise levels in your images. â€¢ Set your camera to shutter priority mode at 1/60s with ISO 200 fixed in a low-light indoor event, capturing the action while evaluating the noise in your shots. â€¢ Use aperture priority mode at f/4 with ISO 200 fixed during a sunset to explore how changing light impacts exposure and noise. â€¢ Select a busy street scene at night and shoot in shutter priority mode at 1/125s with ISO 200 fixed, focusing on the effects of ISO on both sharpness and noise. ðŸ’¡ Stretch Tasks â€¢ Experiment with ISO settings at 400, 800, and 1600 in various lighting environments to analyze how noise increases with higher ISO. â€¢ Capture a series of images at the same aperture and shutter speed but varying ISO settings, then create a visual comparison of noise levels. DO / DON'T DO â€¢ âœ“ Do keep your ISO as low as possible for the best image quality. â€¢ âœ“ Do utilize aperture priority mode to control depth of field while managing ISO. â€¢ âœ“ Do practice in different lighting environments to understand ISO's effect on noise. â€¢ âœ“ Do take notes on the settings used for each shot to analyze results later. â€¢ âœ“ Do review your images at 100% zoom to assess noise levels effectively. DON'T â€¢ âœ— Don't set ISO to auto; choose a fixed value to control noise. â€¢ âœ— Don't ignore the impact of high ISO on image detail and quality. â€¢ âœ— Don't use manual mode for this assignment; focus on priority modes instead. â€¢ âœ— Don't forget to evaluate your images after shooting to understand the effects of your settings. â€¢ âœ— Don't aim for perfect images; focus on understanding the relationship between ISO and noise.
